item.title: Ports Forwardedb but still nothing
item.dc:creator: @tb1 tb
item.description:
@tb1 wrote:

For a colledge student, dont you think its stupid to do something which could be seen as illegal to your fellow students considering your using copywritten material from Jagex, which has attempted to sue many people and this could mess up your total chances. And since your learning java it would be better to just stick with the class or make your own game for practice then something almost considered illegal.

Anyways on topic… If your portforwarded then your pretty much done, though if your only doing it for testing purposes then you didnt have to portforward in the begining to practice java, portforwarding is only to let other people on your server which has nothing to do with the practice of programming in java. Anyways what exactly is your problem? You said you have everything set up and can log into localhost, and thats pretty much it… What are you asking for help with?? programming itself?

Read full topic

item.title: Ports Forwardedb but still nothing
item.dc:creator: @Jerwo0d Jerwo0d
item.description:
@Jerwo0d wrote:

Hi, I’m doing an basic java course in my college, this starts 3 months time. So i thought I’d get a foot in by learning to code first on something I already knew Runescape

I Downloaded my Base, Client, And set off to port forward. I have had no problems in the past port forwarding. In fact Its Forwarded already!
I have Changed my Static IP in advanced. And now have became unstuck.

rooter.jpg783×525

Now to be sure its open using Portforward.com’s Port Checker.
portopen.jpg810×297

So, done. Now i have to do is log into the server, right? Nope. The client logs in with no problems on 127.0.0.1 but as soon as i try and log in via my own IP from www.whatsmyip.com I get nowhere quickly. As I’m 100% new to java and am trying to look at this logically I change my IP in the Gui - here

import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.lang.String; import java.awt.event.*; import java.io.BufferedReader; import java.io.File; import java.io.FileOutputStream; import java.io.InputStreamReader; import java.io.IOException; import java.net.InetAddress; import java.net.URL; import java.util.ArrayList; import java.text.SimpleDateFormat; import java.util.Date; import java.util.Hashtable; import javax.swing.*; import javax.swing.filechooser.FileFilter; import javax.swing.plaf.metal.MetalLookAndFeel; import sign.signlink; import javax.sound.midi.*; import java.util.List; import javax.imageio.ImageIO; import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;

public class Gui extends client
implements ActionListener, ItemListener, WindowListener
{
private static FileOutputStream logFileOut;
private static boolean isApplet = false;
private MP3Player player;
public int midiCount;
public Sequencer sequencer;

public static void main(String args[])
{
	new Gui(args);

}

private Gui(String args[]) 
{
	super();
		try {

		System.out.println("connecting to update server");
		Serverip = "00.000.000.000";    -----------------------------------------------------Here!
		sign.signlink.startpriv(InetAddress.getByName(Serverip));
		initUI();
	} 
	catch(Exception ex)
	{
		ex.printStackTrace();
	}
}</blockquote>

Although it was fairly easy to find this, i cant seem to find anywhere to check my ports are set to 43594 server side or client side, do i need to?

Any help would be highly appreciated!

Thanks
Jerwood

Read full topic
